newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Air NZ 1996/97 profit likely to lower.
newsitem.headline: Air NZ 1996/97 profit likely to lower.

text.p: Air New Zealand said difficult trading conditions had continued into the first two months of its new financial year and consequently the company's full-year profit was likely to be down on last year's NZ$225 million, the New Zealand Press Association reported on Monday.

The company said in its prospectus for the previously announced issue of 121 million shares that earnings for the first half of the 1995/96 financial year were $135.1 million and in the second half earnings declined to $90.1 million.

"While trading in the first two months of the current financial year have been in keeping with last year's second-half performance, it is too early for directors to provide a reliable forecast in terms of the full-year outcome," Air New Zealand said.
"However, assuming that the present difficult trading conditions continue to prevail, the directors expect that earnings for the full year will be below last year's $225 million".

The prospectus said Air New Zealand had recently initiated a rigorous cost reduction programme to reflect the competitive conditions now prevailing "which were expected to continue for the current year".
However, most cost reductions would not be booked until after the second half of the 1996/97 year.
The company noted that as a result of the recently announced purchase of 50 percent of Ansett Australia, Australia had become a very important market for the company.

"While Australia may provide stronger economic growth than is expected in New Zealand over the 1997 financial year, intense competition is expected to continue in the Australian domestic market," Air New Zealand said.

The purchase of the Ansett stake had recently been completed for a total of approximately $540 million. This was being financed by $350 million from existing cash reserves and $190 million of additional borrowing.
The proceeds of the offer of new shares are to be used for general operations and repayment of short-term debt. The offer is expected to raise $242 million.
